page.title: Exhumation and reburial of Richard III of England

revision.text:
{{featured article}} {{Use British English|date=February 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} [[File:King Richard III.jpg|right|thumb|upright=1.4|Richard III, by an unknown artist, late 16th century. The raised right shoulder was a visible sign of Richard's spinal deformity.]] The '''exhumation and reburial of [[Richard III of England|Richard III]]''' began with the discovery of the king's remains within the site of the former [[Greyfriars, Leicester|Greyfriars Friary Church]] in [[Leicester]], England, in September 2012. Following extensive anthropological and genetic testing, the remains of Richard III, the last English king killed in battle, were ultimately reinterred at [[Leicester Cathedral]] on 26 March 2015.
Richard III, the final ruler of the [[House of Plantagenet|Plantagenet dynasty]], was killed on 22 August 1485 in the [[Battle of Bosworth Field]], the last significant battle of the [[Wars of the Roses]]. His body was taken to Greyfriars Friary in Leicester, where it was buried in a crude grave in the friary church. Following the friary's [[Dissolution of the Monasteries|dissolution in 1538]] and subsequent demolition, Richard's tomb was lost. An erroneous account arose that Richard's bones had been thrown into the [[River Soar]] at the nearby Bow Bridge.
A search for Richard's body began in August 2012, initiated by the ''Looking for Richard'' project with the support of the [[Ricardian (Richard III)#Richard III Society|Richard III Society]]. The [[Archaeology|archaeological]] [[Excavation (archaeology)|excavation]] was led by the [[University of Leicester#College of Arts, Humanities & Law|University of Leicester Archaeological Services]], working in partnership with [[Leicester City Council]]. On the first day a human skeleton belonging to a man in his thirties was uncovered showing signs of severe injuries. The skeleton, which had several unusual physical features, most notably [[Scoliosis|a severe curvature of the back]] was exhumed to allow scientific analysis. Examination showed that the man had probably been killed either by a blow from a large bladed weapon, probably a [[halberd]], which cut off the back of his skull and exposed the brain, or by a sword thrust that penetrated all the way through the brain. Other wounds on the skeleton had probably occurred after death as "humiliation injuries", inflicted as a form of posthumous revenge.
The age of the bones at death matched that of Richard when he was killed; they were dated to about the period of his death and were mostly consistent with physical descriptions of the king. Preliminary [[Genetic testing|DNA analysis]] showed that [[mitochondrial DNA]] extracted from the bones matched that of two [[matrilineal]] descendants, one 17th-generation and the other 19th-generation, of Richard's sister [[Anne of York, Duchess of Exeter|Anne of York]]. Taking these findings into account along with other historical, scientific and archaeological evidence, the University of Leicester announced on 4 February 2013 that it had concluded beyond reasonable doubt that the skeleton was that of Richard III.
As a condition of being allowed to disinter the skeleton, the archaeologists agreed that, if Richard were found, his remains would be reburied in Leicester Cathedral. A controversy arose as to whether an alternative reburial site, [[York Minster]] or [[Westminster Abbey]], would be more suitable. A legal challenge confirmed there were no public law grounds for the courts to be involved in that decision. Reinterment took place in Leicester on 26 March 2015, during a televised memorial service held in the presence of the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]] and senior members of other Christian denominations.
==Death and initial burial== {{main article|Battle of Bosworth Field}} [[File:Battle of Bosworth by James Doyle.jpg|right|thumb|An 1864 conception of Richard III in the Battle of Bosworth]]
Richard was killed fighting [[Henry VII of England|Henry Tudor]] at the Battle of Bosworth in 1485, the last major battle of the [[Wars of the Roses]]. The Welsh poet [[Guto'r Glyn]] credited Richard's death to Sir [[Rhys ap Thomas]], a Welsh member of Henry's army who was said to have struck the fatal blow.{{sfnp|Rees|2008|p=212}} Following his death, Richard's body was stripped naked and taken to Leicester{{sfnp|Hipshon|2009|p=25}}{{sfnp|Rhodes|1997|p=45}} where it was put on public display. The anonymous ''[[Ballad of Bosworth Field]]'' says that "in Newarke laid was hee, that many a one might looke on him" —almost certainly a reference to the collegiate [[Church of the Annunciation of Our Lady of the Newarke]],<ref>{{cite web|title=The Newarke and the Church of the Annunciation|url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/history/newarkeandchurch.html|publisher=[[University of Leicester]]|accessdate=27 March 2015}}</ref> a Lancastrian foundation on the outskirts of medieval Leicester.<ref>[[#Morris|Morris & Buckley]], p. 22.</ref> According to the chronicler [[Polydore Vergil]], Henry VII "tarried for two days" in Leicester before leaving for London, and on the same date as Henry's departure—25 August 1485—Richard's body was buried "at the convent of Franciscan monks [''sic''] in Leicester" with "no funeral solemnity".<ref name=Carson8>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], p. 8.</ref> The Warwickshire priest and [[Antiquary#Medieval and early modern antiquarianism|antiquary]] John Rous, writing between 1486 and 1491, recorded that Richard had been buried "in the choir of the Friars Minor at Leicester".<ref name=Carson8 /> Although later writers ascribed Richard's burial to other places, the accounts of Vergil and Rous were seen by modern investigators as the most credible.<ref name=Carson19>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], p. 19.</ref>
===Burial site=== {{Main article|Greyfriars, Leicester#Post-dissolution development|l1=Greyfriars, Leicester}} [[File:Greyfriars, Leicestershire Council Offices building.JPG|thumb|No 1, Grey Friars, County Offices for Leicestershire County Council from 1936 to 1965, occupies the site of the Herrick mansion.]] In 1495, ten years after the burial, Henry VII paid for a marble and alabaster monument to mark Richard's grave.{{sfnp|Baldwin|1986|pp=21–22}} Its cost is recorded in surviving legal papers relating to a dispute over payment showing that two men received payments of £50 and [[£sd|£10.1s]] respectively to make and transport the tomb from Nottingham to Leicester.<ref name=Carson18>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], p. 18.</ref> No first-person descriptions of the tomb survive, but [[Raphael Holinshed]] wrote in 1577 (perhaps quoting someone who had seen it in person) that it incorporated "a picture of alabaster representing [Richard's] person".<ref name=Carson17>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], p. 17.</ref> Sir [[George Buck]] 40 years later wrote that it was "a fair tomb of mingled colour marble adorned with his image".<ref name=Carson17 /> Buck also recorded the epitaph inscribed on the tomb.<ref name=Carson17 />
Following the [[Dissolution of the Monasteries|dissolution]] of Greyfriars in 1538, the friary was demolished and the monument either was destroyed, or slowly decayed as a result of being exposed to the elements. The site of the friary was sold to two Lincolnshire property speculators and was later acquired by Robert Herrick, the Mayor of Leicester. Herrick built a mansion close to Friary Lane, on a site that is now buried under the modern Grey Friars Street, and turned the rest of the land into gardens.<ref name=Morris26>[[#Morris|Morris & Buckley]], p. 26.</ref> Although Richard's monument had evidently disappeared by this time, the site of his grave was still known. The antiquary Christopher Wren (father of [[Christopher Wren]] the architect) recorded that Herrick erected a monument on the site of the grave in the form of a stone pillar three feet (1 m) high carved with the words, "Here lies the Body of Richard III, Some Time King of England."<ref name=Carson20>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], p. 20.</ref> The pillar was visible in 1612 but had disappeared by 1844.{{sfnp|Halsted|1844|p=401}}
The [[cartographer]] and antiquarian [[John Speed]] wrote in his ''Historie of Great Britaine'' (1611) that local tradition held that Richard's body had been "borne out of the City, and contemptuously bestowed under the end of Bow-Bridge, which giveth passage over a branch of Soare upon the west side of the town."<ref name=Morris28>[[#Morris|Morris & Buckley]], p. 28.</ref> His account was widely accepted by later authors. In 1856 a memorial plaque to Richard III was erected next to Bow Bridge by a local builder, stating, "Near this spot lie the remains of Richard III the last of the Plantagenets 1485".<ref name=Morris29 /> The discovery of a skeleton in 1862 in the river sediments near the bridge led to claims that Richard's bones had been found, but closer examination showed they were probably those of a man in his early 20s and not Richard's.<ref name=Morris29 />
The origin of Speed's claim is unclear; it was not attributed to any source, nor did it have any antecedents in other written accounts.<ref name=Morris29>[[#Morris|Morris & Buckley]], p. 29.</ref> The writer Audrey Strange suggests that the account may be a confused retelling of [[desecration]] of the remains of [[John Wycliffe]] in nearby [[Lutterworth]] in 1428, when a mob disinterred him, burned his bones and threw them into the [[River Swift]].<ref name=Carson22>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], p. 22.</ref> The independent British historian John Ashdown-Hill proposes that Speed made a mistake over the location of Richard's grave and invented the story to account for its absence. If Speed had been to Herrick's property he would surely have seen the commemorative pillar and gardens, but instead he reported that the site was "overgrown with nettles and weeds"{{sfnp|Langley|Jones|2014|pp=7, 10}} and there was no trace of Richard's grave. The map of Leicester drawn by Speed incorrectly shows Greyfriars where the former Blackfriars was, suggesting that he had looked for the grave in the wrong place.{{sfnp|Langley|Jones|2014|pp=7, 10}}
Another local legend arose about a stone coffin that supposedly held Richard's remains, which Speed wrote was "now made a drinking trough for horses at a common Inn". A coffin certainly seems to have existed; [[John Evelyn]] recorded it on a visit in 1654, and [[Celia Fiennes]] wrote in 1700 that she had seen "a piece of his tombstone [''sic''] he lay in, which was cut out in exact form for his body to lie in; it remains to be seen at ye Greyhound [Inn] in Leicester but is partly broken." [[William Hutton (historian)|William Hutton]] found in 1758 that the coffin, which had "not withstood the ravages of time", was kept at the White Horse Inn on Gallowtree Gate. Although the coffin's location is no longer known, its description does not match the style of late 15th-century coffins, and it is unlikely to have had any connection with Richard. It is more likely that it was salvaged from one of the religious establishments demolished following the Dissolution.<ref name=Morris29 />
Herrick's mansion, Greyfriars House, remained in the possession of his family until his great-grandson Samuel sold it in 1711. The property was subsequently divided and sold in 1740; three years later, New Street was built across the western part of the site. Many burials were discovered when houses were laid out along the street. A townhouse, 17 Friar Lane, was built on the eastern part of the site in 1759 and survives today. During the 19th century, the site became increasingly built on. In 1863 [[Alderman Newton's School|Alderman Newton's Boys' School]] built a schoolhouse on part of the site. Herrick's mansion was demolished in 1871, the present Grey Friars Street was laid through the site in 1873, and more commercial developments, including the Leicester Trustee Savings Bank, were built. In 1915 the rest of the site was acquired by [[Leicestershire County Council]] which built offices on it in the 1920s and 1930s. The council relocated in 1965 when its new County Hall opened, and Leicester City Council moved in.<ref name="Morris29"/> The rest of the site, where Herrick's garden had once been, was turned into a staff car park in about 1944, but was not otherwise built on.<ref>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], pp. 35, 46.</ref>
In 2007, a single-storey building from the 1950s was demolished on Grey Friars Street giving archaeologists the opportunity to excavate and search for traces of the medieval friary. Very little was unearthed, except for a fragment of a post-medieval stone coffin lid. The results of the dig suggested that the remains of the friary church were farther west than previously thought.<ref name="RB-June2012">{{cite journal |title=The Man Himself: Looking for Richard: In Search of a King |journal=Ricardian Bulletin |last=Langley |first=Philippa |date=June 2012 |pages=26–28 |publisher=Richard III Society |url=http://issuu.com/richard_third/docs/2012_06_june_bulletin?e=7156033/9963539}}</ref>
==''Looking for Richard'' project== [[File:Bow Bridge Richard III plaques.jpg|right|thumb|Plaques on Bow Bridge, Leicester, relating to the story that Richard's bones had been dumped into the River Soar. The small plaque was installed by the Richard III Society in 2005 to refute the statement on the larger plaque, installed in 1856.]] The location of Richard III's body has long been of interest to the members of the [[Ricardian (Richard III)#Richard III Society|Richard III Society]], a group established to bring about a reappraisal of the King's tarnished reputation. In 1975 an article by Audrey Strange was published in the society's journal, ''The Ricardian'', suggesting that his remains were buried under Leicester City Council's car park.<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Grey Friars, Leicester |journal=The Ricardian |last=Strange |first=Audrey |date=September 1975 |volume=3| number=no. 50 |pages=3–7 |publisher=Richard III Society}}</ref> The claim was repeated in 1986, when historian [[David Baldwin (historian)|David Baldwin]] suggested that the remains were still in the Greyfriars area.{{sfnp|Baldwin|1986|p=24}} He speculated, "It is possible (though now perhaps unlikely) that at some time in the twenty-first century an excavator may yet reveal the slight remains of this famous monarch."<ref name=Carson25>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], p. 25.</ref> In 2004 and 2005, John Ashdown-Hill tracked down two 17th-generation [[Matrilineality|matrilineal]] descendants of Richard III's sister [[Anne of York, Duchess of Exeter|Anne of York]].<ref>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], pp. 29–30.</ref> He concluded from his knowledge of the layout of Franciscan priories that the ruins of the priory church at Greyfriars were likely to lie under the car park and had not been built over.<ref name=Carson31>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], p. 31.</ref>
Although the Richard III Society remained interested in discussing the possible location of the king's grave, they did not search for his remains. Individual members suggested possible lines of investigation, but neither the University of Leicester nor local historians and archaeologists took up the challenge, probably because it was widely thought that the grave site had been built over or the skeleton had been scattered, as John Speed's account suggested.<ref>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], pp. 26–27.</ref>
In 2004 and 2005, [[Philippa Langley]], secretary of the Scottish Branch of the Richard III Society, carried out research in Leicester in connection with a biographical Richard III screenplay. She became convinced that the car park was the key location for investigation and contacted Ashdown-Hill after hearing of his DNA research.<ref>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], pp. 31–32.</ref> At her urging, he contacted the producers of [[Channel 4]]'s ''[[Time Team]]'' archaeology series to propose an excavation of the car park, but they declined as the dig would take longer than the standard three-day window for ''Time Team'' projects. Three years later, another writer, Annette Carson, in her book ''Richard III: The Maligned King'' (2008), independently came to the conclusion that his body probably lay under the car park. She joined forces with Langley and Ashdown-Hill to carry out further research,<ref name=Carson32>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], p. 32.</ref> in the course of which she found what she called a "smoking gun"—a medieval map of Leicester showing the Greyfriars Church at the north end of what was now the car park.{{sfnp|Langley|Jones|2014|p=11}}
In February 2009, Langley, Carson and Ashdown-Hill teamed up with Richard III Society members—Dr David Johnson and his wife Wendy—to launch a project with the working title ''Looking for Richard: In Search of a King'', which Langley envisaged as a "landmark TV special".<ref name="RB-June2012" /> Its premise was a search for Richard's grave "while at the same time telling his real story",<ref name="RB-June2012" /><ref name="Radio Times">{{cite news |url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2013-02-04/meet-philippa-langley-the-woman-who-discovered-richard-iii-in-a-car-park |title=Meet Philippa Langley: the woman who discovered Richard III in a car park |work=Radio Times |date=2 April 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> with an objective "to search for, recover and rebury his mortal remains with the honour, dignity and respect so conspicuously denied following his death at the battle of Bosworth."<ref name=Carson36>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], p. 36.</ref>
The project gained the backing of several key partners—Leicester City Council, Leicester Promotions (responsible for tourist marketing), the University of Leicester, Leicester Cathedral, Darlow Smithson Productions (responsible for the planned TV show) and the Richard III Society.<ref name="Radio Times" /> Funding for the initial phase of pre-excavation research came from the Richard III Society's bursary fund and members of the ''Looking for Richard'' project,{{sfnp|Langley|Jones|2014|pp=22, 26}} with Leicester Promotions agreeing to pick up the £35,000 cost of the dig. The University of Leicester Archaeological Services—an independent body with offices at the university—was appointed as the project's archaeological contractor.{{sfnp|Langley|Jones|2014|pp= 21, 24}}
==Greyfriars project and excavations== [[File:Greyfriars, Leicester site.svg|thumb|300px|Site of Greyfriars, shown superimposed over a modern map of the area. The skeleton of Richard III was recovered in September 2012 from the centre of the choir, shown by a small dot.]] In March 2011 an assessment of the Greyfriars site began to identify where the monastery had stood, and which land might be available for excavation. A desk-based assessment<ref group=note>A desk-based assessment involves gathering together the written, graphic, photographic and electronic information that already exists about a site to help identify the likely character, extent, and quality of the known or suspected remains or structures being researched.</ref> was conducted to determine the archaeological viability of the site, followed by a survey in August 2011 using [[ground-penetrating radar]] (GPR).<ref name="RB-June2012" /> The GPR results were inconclusive; no clear building remains could be identified owing to a layer of disturbed ground and demolition debris just below the surface. The survey was useful in finding modern utilities crossing the site, such as pipes and cables.<ref name=Carson48>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], p. 48.</ref>
Three possible excavation sites were identified: the staff car park of Leicester City Council [[Social Services]], the disused playground of the former Alderman Newton's School and a public car park on New Street. It was decided to open two trenches in the Social Services car park, with an option for a third in the playground.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/archaeology/wherewedug.html|title=Where we dug|publisher=University of Leicester|date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> Because most of the Greyfriars site had been built on, only seventeen per cent of its former area was available to excavate; the area to be investigated amounted to just one per cent of the site, owing to the limitations of the project's funding.{{sfnp|Langley|Jones|2014|p=56}}
The proposed excavation was announced in the June 2012 issue of the Richard III Society's magazine, the ''Ricardian Bulletin'', but a month later one of the main sponsors pulled out leaving a £10,000 funding shortfall; an appeal resulted in members of the several Ricardian groups donating £13,000 in two weeks.<ref name="RB-Sept2012">{{cite journal |title=Update: Looking for Richard: In Search of a King |journal=Ricardian Bulletin |last=Langley |first=Philippa |date=September 2012 |pages=14–15 |publisher=Richard III Society |url=http://issuu.com/richard_third/docs/2012_09_september_bulletin?e=7156033/9963536}}</ref> A press conference held in Leicester on 24 August announced the start of the work. Archaeologist Richard Buckley admitted the project was a long shot: "We don't know precisely where the church is, let alone where the burial site is."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/history/9497082/Digging-for-dirt-on-the-Hunchback-King.html |title=Digging for dirt on the Hunchback King |last=Rainey |first=Sarah |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=25 August 2012 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> He had earlier told Langley that he thought the odds were "fifty-fifty at best for [finding] the church, and nine-to-one against finding the grave."{{sfnp|Langley|Jones|2014|p=21}}
Digging began the next day with a trench {{convert|1.6|m|ft}} wide by {{convert|30|m|ft}} long, running roughly north-south. A layer of modern building debris was removed before the level of the former monastery was reached. Two parallel human leg bones were discovered about {{convert|5|m|ft}} from the north end of the trench at a depth of about {{convert|1.5|m|ft}}, indicating an undisturbed burial.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/archaeology/25august.html |title=Saturday 25 August 2012 |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> The bones were covered temporarily to protect them while excavations continued further along the trench. A second, parallel trench was dug next day to the south-west.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/archaeology/26august.html |title=Sunday 26 August 2012 |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> Over the following days, evidence of medieval walls and rooms was uncovered, allowing the archaeologists to pinpoint the area of the friary.<ref name="27Aug"/> It became clear that the bones found on the first day lay inside the east part of the church, possibly the choir, where Richard was said to have been buried.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/archaeology/1september.html |title=1 September |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> On 31 August, the University of Leicester applied for a licence from the [[Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Justice]] to permit the exhumation of up to six sets of human remains. To narrow the search, it was planned that only the remains of men in their thirties, buried within the church, would be exhumed.<ref name="27Aug">{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/archaeology/27august.html |title=Monday 27 to Friday 31 August 2012 |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref>
The bones found on 25 August were uncovered on 4 September and the grave soil dug back further over the next two days. The feet were missing, and the skull was found in an unusual propped-up position, consistent with the body being put into a grave that was slightly too small.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/press/media-centre/richard-iii/press-conference-4-february/presentations-by-speakers-at-the-press-conference-monday-4-february-1/lead-archaeologist-richard-buckley-gives-key-evidence-from-the-dig-site |title=Lead archaeologist Richard Buckley gives key evidence from the dig site|publisher=University of Leicester |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> The spine was curved in an S-shape. No sign of a coffin was found; the skeleton's posture suggested the body had not been put in a [[shroud]], but had been hurriedly dumped into the grave and buried. As the bones were lifted from the ground, a piece of rusted iron was found underneath the vertebrae.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/archaeology/5september.html |title=Wednesday 5 September 2012 |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/archaeology/5septembercont.html |title=Wednesday 5 September 2012 (continued) |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013}}</ref> The skeleton's hands were in an unusual position, crossed over the right hip, suggesting they were tied together at the time of burial, although this could not be established definitively.<ref name="Osteology">{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/science/osteology.html |title=Osteology|publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> After the exhumation, work continued in the trenches over the following week, before the site was covered with soil to protect it from damage and re-surfaced to restore the car park and playground to their former condition.<ref name="8Sep">{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/archaeology/8september.html |title=Saturday 8 to Friday 14 September 2012 |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref>
==Analysis of the discovery== [[File:Richard III burial site.jpg|right|thumb|The site of Richard III's grave, against a wall in the choir of the former Greyfriars Church]] [[File:Archaeologist working in Trench.jpg|right|thumb|Archaeologists working in a trench in the playground of the former Alderman Newton's School, on the site of the Greyfriars Church, in September 2012]] On 12 September, the University of Leicester team announced that the human remains were a possible candidate for Richard's body, but emphasised the need for caution. The positive indicators were that the body was of an adult male; it was buried beneath the choir of the church; it had severe [[scoliosis]] of the spine possibly making one shoulder higher than the other.<ref>{{cite web |title=Richard III Society pays tribute to exemplary archaeological research |url=http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/press/media-centre/non-university-press-releases/richard-iii-society-pays-tribute-to-exemplary-archaeological-research |date=15 October 2012 |publisher=University of Leicester |accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> An object that appeared to be an arrowhead was found under the spine and the skull had severe injuries.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/FINAL-RESTING-PLACE-KING/story-16893072-detail/story.html |title=Richard III dig: Eyes of world on Leicester as Greyfriars skeleton find revealed |newspaper=Leicester Mercury |date=13 September 2012 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="Guardian13Sep2012">{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/science/2012/sep/12/richard-skeleton-king-remains-bosworth |title=Richard III: Could the skeleton under the car park be the king's? |last=Wainwright |first=Martin |newspaper=The Guardian |date=13 September 2012 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref>
===DNA evidence=== After the exhumation the emphasis shifted from the excavation to laboratory analysis of the bones that had been recovered. Ashdown-Hill had used [[genealogy|genealogical research]] to track down matrilineal descendants of Anne of York, Richard's older sister, whose matrilineal line of descent is extant through her daughter [[Anne St Leger, Baroness de Ros|Anne St Leger]]. Academic [[Kevin Schürer]] subsequently traced a second individual in the same line.<ref>{{cite web |title=Richard III – University of Leicester press statement following permission judgment |url=http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/press/press-releases/2013/august/richard-iii-university-of-leicester-press-statement-following-permission-judgment |publisher=University of Leicester |date=16 August 2013 |accessdate=22 August 2013}}</ref>
Ashdown-Hill's research came about as a result of a challenge in 2003 to provide a DNA sequence for Richard's sister [[Margaret of York|Margaret]], to identify bones found in her burial place, the Franciscan priory church in [[Mechelen]], Belgium. He tried to extract a [[mitochondrial DNA#Female inheritance|mitochondrial DNA]] sequence from a preserved hair from [[Edward IV of England|Edward IV]] held by the [[Ashmolean Museum]] in [[Oxford]] but the attempt proved unsuccessful, owing to degradation of the DNA. Ashdown-Hill turned instead to genealogical research to identify an all-female-line descendant of [[Cecily Neville, Duchess of York|Cecily Neville]], Richard's mother.<ref name="JAH-Dec2012">{{cite journal |title=The Search for Richard III – DNA, documentary evidence and religious knowledge |journal=Ricardian Bulletin |last=Ashdown-Hill |first=John |date=December 2012 |pages=31–32 |publisher=Richard III Society |url=http://issuu.com/richard_third/docs/2012_12_bulletin_text/1}}</ref> After two years he found a British-born woman who had emigrated to Canada after [[World War II]], Joy Ibsen (née Brown), was a direct descendant of Richard's sister, Anne of York (and therefore Richard's 16th-generation great-niece).<ref name=RichIIIftree>{{cite web |title=Family tree: Cecily Neville (1415–1495) Duchess of York |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/science/familytree.html |publisher=University of Leicester |accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Richard III dig: 'It does look like him' |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21319332 |publisher=BBC News |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> Ibsen's mitochondrial DNA was tested and found to belong to [[Haplogroup J (mtDNA)|mitochondrial DNA Haplogroup J]], which by deduction should be Richard's mitochondrial DNA haplogroup.<ref>Ibsen's mtDNA sequence: 16069T, 16126C, 73G, 146C, 185A, 188G, 263G, 295T, 315.1C in Ashdown-Hill, John (2013), p. 161.</ref> The mtDNA obtained from Ibsen showed that the Mechelen bones were not those of Margaret.<ref name="JAH-Dec2012" />
Joy Ibsen, a retired journalist, died in 2008, leaving three children: Michael, Jeff and Leslie.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/science/relatives.html|title=Living Relatives|last=Anon|work=The Discovery of Richard III|publisher=University of Leicester|accessdate=26 March 2015}}</ref> On 24 August 2012, her son Michael (born in Canada in 1957, a cabinet maker death|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/earth/environment/archaeology/11489187/Richard-III-burial-five-centuries-on-the-last-medieval-king-finally-gains-honour-in-death.html|last=Rowley|first=Tom|date=23 The other living female-line relative of Richard III, since named as New Zealander Wendy Duldig, is a 19th-generation descendant of Anne of York; their female lines of descent separated after Anne of York's granddaughter Catherine Manners. Duldig's mitochondrial DNA is a match apart from one mutation.<ref name=RichIIIftree/> Wendy Duldig has no surviving children.
Despite the matching mitochondrial DNA, geneticist Turi King continued to pursue a link between the paternally-inherited [[Human Y-chromosome DNA haplogroup|Y-DNA]] and that of descendants of [[John of Gaunt]]. Four living male-line descendants of Gaunt have been located, and their results are a match to each other. The Y-DNA from the skeleton is somewhat degraded, but proved not to match any of the living male-line relatives, showing that a [[false-paternity event]] had happened somewhere in the 19 generations between Richard III and [[Henry Somerset, 5th Duke of Beaufort]]; work by Turi King and others has shown that historical rates of [[Non-paternity event|false paternity]] are around 1–2% per generation.<ref name=dnaresultrichiii/>
===Bones=== An [[osteology|osteological]] examination of the bones showed them to be in generally good condition and largely complete except for the missing feet, which may have been destroyed by Victorian building work. It was immediately apparent that the body had suffered major injuries, and further evidence of wounds was found as the skeleton was cleaned.<ref name="Osteology" /> The skull shows signs of two lethal injuries; the base of the back of the skull had been completely cut away by a bladed weapon, which would have exposed the brain, and another bladed weapon had been thrust through the right side of the skull, striking the inside of the left side through the brain.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/science/osteologyskull.html |title=Injuries to the skull 1 – 2 |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> Elsewhere on the skull, a blow from a pointed weapon had penetrated the crown of the head. Bladed weapons had clipped the skull and sheared off layers of bone, without penetrating it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/science/osteologyskull3.html |title=Injuries to the skull 3 – 6 |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013}}</ref> Other holes in the skull and lower jaw were found to be consistent with dagger wounds to the chin and cheek.<ref name="Skull7-8">{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/science/osteologyskull3.html |title=Injuries to the skull 7 – 8 |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> The multiple wounds on the king’s skull indicated that he was not wearing his helmet, which he may have removed or lost when he was on foot after his horse had become stuck in the marsh.<ref>{{cite news |title=King Richard III was probably hacked and stabbed to death in battle, according to a new study |author=Kirkpatrick, Nick |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/09/17/king-richard-iii-died-a-painful-death-according-to-a-new-study |newspaper=Washington Post |date=17 September 2014| accessdate=18 September 2014}}</ref><ref name=Appleby>{{cite journal |displayauthors=1 |first1=J |last1=Appleby |first2=G |last3=Hainsworth |first3=Sarah V |last4=Woosnam-Savage |first4=Robert C |last5=Morgan |first5=Bruno |last6=Brough |first6=Alison |last7=Earp |first7=Richard W |last8=Robinson |first8=Claire |last9=King |first9=Turi E |last10=Morris |first10=Mathew |last11=Buckley |first11=Richard |last2=Rutty |title=Perimortem trauma in King Richard III: a skeletal analysis |journal=The Lancet |volume=385 |issue=9964 |page=253 |date=17 September 2014 |publisher=Elsevier |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(14)60804-7 |url=http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(14)60804-7/fulltext}}</ref> One of his right ribs had been cut by a sharp implement, as had the pelvis.<ref name="Body">{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/science/osteologybody.html |title=Injuries to the body 9 – 10 |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> There was no evidence of the withered arm that afflicted the character in [[William Shakespeare]]'s play ''[[Richard III (play)|Richard III]]''.<ref name="What the bones"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/science-news/9849541/Graphic-Richard-IIIs-injuries-and-how-he-died.html |title=Graphic: Richard III's injuries and how he died |date=5 February 2013 |newspaper=The Telegraph |accessdate=7 September 2013}}</ref>
Taken together, the injuries appear to be a combination of battle wounds, which were the cause of death, followed by post-mortem humiliation wounds inflicted on the corpse. The body wounds show that the corpse had been stripped of its armour, as the stabbed torso would have been protected by a backplate and the pelvis would have been protected by armour. The wounds were made from behind on the back and buttocks while they were exposed to the elements, consistent with the contemporary descriptions of Richard's naked body being tied across a horse with the legs and arms dangling down on either side.<ref name="Skull7-8"/><ref name="Body" /><ref name="Armouries" /> There may have been further flesh wounds not apparent from the bones.<ref name="What the bones">{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/science/whattheonesdontsay.html |title=What the bones can and can’t tell us |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref>
The head wounds are consistent with a 1485 poem by Guto'r Glyn in which a Welsh knight, Sir Rhys ap Thomas killed Richard and "shaved the boar's head".<ref name="BBC-15-Feb-2013" /> It had been thought that this was a figurative description of Richard being decapitated, but the skeleton's head had clearly not been severed. Guto's description may instead be a literal account of the injuries that Richard suffered, as the blows sustained to the head would have sliced away much of his scalp and hair and slivers of bone.<ref name="BBC-15-Feb-2013">{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-21441319 |title=Richard III wounds match medieval Welsh poem description |date=15 February 2013 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> Other contemporary sources refer explicitly to head injuries and the weapons used to kill Richard; the French chronicler [[Jean Molinet]] wrote that "one of the Welshmen then came after him, and struck him dead with a [[halberd]]", and the ''Ballad of Lady Bessie'' recorded that "they struck his [[bascinet]] to his head until his brains came out with blood." Such accounts would certainly fit the damage inflicted on the skull.<ref name="Armouries">{{cite web |url=http://www.royalarmouries.org/what-we-do/press/armouries-finds-king-in-the-car-park |title=Armouries finds King in the Car Park |publisher=Royal Armouries |accessdate=27 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Bosworth: The Birth of the Tudors |last=Skidmore |first=Chris |publisher=Phoenix |year=2014 |page=309 |isbn=978-0-7538-2894-6}}</ref>
Sideways curvature of his spine was evident as the skeleton was excavated. It has been attributed to adolescent-onset [[scoliosis]]. Although it was probably visible in making his right shoulder higher than the left and reducing his apparent height, it did not preclude an active lifestyle, and would not have caused a [[hunchback]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/science/spine.html |title=Spine |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> The bones are those of a male with an age range estimation of 30–34,<ref name=Appleby /> consistent with Richard, who was 32 when he died.<ref name="What the bones"/>
===Radiocarbon dating and other scientific analyses=== Two [[radiocarbon dating]]s to find the age of the bones suggested dates of 1430–60<ref group=note>Scottish Universities Environmental Research Centre (SUERC)</ref> and 1412–49<ref group=note>[[University of Oxford]]'s [[Research Laboratory for Archaeology and the History of Art|Radiocarbon Accelerator Unit]]</ref>—both too early for Richard's death in 1485. [[Mass spectrometry]] carried out on the bones found evidence of much [[seafood]] consumption, which is known to make [[radiocarbon dating]] samples appear older than they are. A [[Bayesian inference|Bayesian]] analysis suggested there was a 68.2% probability that the true date of the bones was between 1475 and 1530, rising to 95.4% for between 1450 and 1540. Although by itself not enough to prove that the skeleton was Richard's, it was consistent with the date of his death.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/science/carbondating.html|title=Radiocarbon dating and analysis|publisher=University of Leicester|date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> The mass spectrometry result indicating the rich seafood diet was confirmed by a chemical [[isotope analysis]] of two teeth, a femur and a rib. From the isotope analysis of carbon, nitrogen and oxygen in the teeth and bones the researchers discovered the diet included much freshwater fish and exotic birds such as [[swan]], [[Crane (bird)|crane]] and [[heron]], and a vast quantity of wine — all items at the high end of the luxury market.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/26/science/richard-iiis-rich-diet-of-fish-and-exotic-birds.html?ref=science&_r=0 |title=Richard III's Rich Diet of Fish and Exotic Birds |author=Quenqua, Douglas |newspaper=The New York Times |date=25 August 2014 |accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref> Close analysis of the soil immediately below the skeleton revealed that the man had been infested with [[roundworm]] parasites at the time of his death.<ref name="BA141" />
The excavators found an iron object under the skeleton's vertebrae and speculated it might be an arrowhead that had been embedded in its back. An [[X-ray]] analysis showed it was a nail, probably of [[Roman Britain|Romano-British]] date, that by chance had been in the ground immediately under the grave or was in soil disturbed when it was dug and had nothing to do with the body.<ref name="What the bones"/>
==Identification of Richard III and other findings== On 4 February 2013, the University of Leicester confirmed that the skeleton was that of Richard III.<ref name=Discovery /><ref>{{cite web|title=The search for Richard III – completed|url=http://www.le.ac.uk/richardiii/index.html|publisher=University of Leicester |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leicestershire-21063882|title=Richard III dig: DNA confirms bones are king's|publisher=BBC|date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> The identification was based on [[mitochondrial DNA]] evidence, soil analysis, and dental tests, and physical characteristics of the skeleton consistent with contemporary accounts of Richard's appearance. Osteoarchaeologist Jo Appleby commented: "The skeleton has a number of unusual features: its slender build, the scoliosis, and the battle-related trauma. All of these are highly consistent with the information that we have about Richard III in life and about the circumstances of his death."<ref name=Discovery>{{cite web |url=http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/press/press-releases/2013/february/university-of-leicester-announces-discovery-of-king-richard-iii |title=University of Leicester announces discovery of King Richard III |publisher=University of Leicester |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref>
[[Caroline Wilkinson]], Professor of [[Craniofacial]] Identification at the [[University of Dundee]], led the project to reconstruct the face, commissioned by the Richard III Society.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/02/05/world/europe/richard-iii-reconstruction/index.html |title=Richard III: Is this the face that launched 1,000 myths? |first=Susannah |last=Cullinane |work=CNN.com |date=5 February 2013 |accessdate=7 February 2013}}</ref> On 11 February 2014, the University of Leicester announced a project headed by Turi King to sequence the entire genome of Richard III and Michael Ibsen—a direct female-line descendant of Richard's sister, Anne of York – whose mitochondrial DNA confirmed the identification of the excavated remains. Richard III is thus the first ancient person with known historical identity whose genome has been sequenced.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/press/press-releases/2014/february/genomes-of-richard-iii-and-his-proven-relative-to-be-sequenced |title=Genomes of Richard III and his proven relative to be sequenced |publisher=University of Leicester |date=11 February 2014 |accessdate=16 March 2014}}</ref> A study published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' in December 2014 confirmed a perfect whole-mitochondrial genome match between Richard's skeleton and Michael Ibsen and a near-perfect match between Richard and his other confirmed living relative. However, [[Y chromosome]] DNA inherited via the male line found no link with five other claimed living relatives, indicating that at least one "[[false-paternity]] event" occurred in the generations between Richard and these men. One of these five was found to be unrelated to the other four, showing that another false-paternity event had occurred in the four generations separating them.<ref>[[#K1|King, Gonzalez Fortes, Balaresque et al (2014)]]</ref>
The story of the excavation and subsequent scientific investigation was told in a Channel 4 documentary, ''Richard III: The King in the Car Park'', broadcast on 4 February 2013.<ref>{{cite web |title=Richard III: The King in the Car Park |url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/richard-iii-the-king-in-the-car-park/episode-guide/series-1/episode-1 |publisher=Channel 4 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> It proved a ratings hit for the channel, watched by up to 4.9 million viewers,<ref name="Channel4">{{cite news |url=http://www.channel4.com/info/press/news/following-hit-doc-more4-to-screen-richard-iii-the-unseen-story |title=Following hit doc, More4 to screen Richard III: The Unseen Story |publisher=Channel 4 News |date=13 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> and won a [[Royal Television Society]] award.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/press/press-releases/2014/march/2018king-in-the-car-park2019-documentary-wins-top-television-award |title=‘King in the Car Park’ documentary wins top television award |publisher=University of Leicester |date=20 March 2014 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> Channel 4 subsequently screened a follow-up documentary on 27 February 2014, ''Richard III: The Untold Story'', which detailed the scientific and archaeological analyses that led to the identification of the skeleton as Richard III.<ref name="Channel4" />
[[File:Grey Friars July 2013 excavation.jpg|right|thumb|The July 2013 excavation, which uncovered more of Greyfriars and exhumed several other burials]] The site was re-excavated in July 2013 to learn more about the friary church, before building work on the adjacent disused school building. In a project co-funded by Leicester City Council and the University of Leicester, a single trench about twice the area of the 2012 trenches was excavated. It succeeded in exposing the entirety of the sites of the Greyfriars presbytery and choir sites, confirming archaeologists' earlier hypotheses about the layout of the church's east end. Three burials identified but not excavated in the 2012 project were tackled afresh. One burial was found to have been interred in a wooden coffin in a well-dug grave, while a second wooden-coffined burial was found under and astride the choir and presbytery; its position suggests that it pre-dates the church.<ref name="BA133" />
A stone coffin found during the 2012 excavation was opened for the first time, revealing a [[lead]] coffin inside. An investigation with an [[endoscope]] revealed the presence of a skeleton along with some head hair and fragments of a shroud and cord.<ref name="BA133">{{cite news |title=Richard III update: a coffin, walls and reburial |work=British Archaeology |issue=133 |date=November–December 2013 |last=Pitts |first=Mike |pages=6–7}}</ref> The skeleton was at first assumed to be male, perhaps that of a knight called Sir William de Moton who was known to have been buried there, but later examination showed it to be of a woman—perhaps a high-ranking benefactress.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/New-twist-mystery-lead-coffin-near-Richard-III/story-19946113-detail/story.html |title=New twist in mystery of lead coffin found near Richard III’s grave |newspaper=Leicester Mercury |date=17 October 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> She may not necessarily have been local, as lead coffins were used to transport corpses over long distances.<ref name="BA133" />
===Plans and challenges=== The University of Leicester's plan to inter Richard's body in [[Leicester Cathedral]] was in keeping with British legal norms which hold that Christian burials excavated by archaeologists should be reburied in the nearest consecrated ground to the original grave<ref name="BA141" /> and was a condition of the licence granted by the [[Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Justice]] to exhume any human remains found during the excavation.<ref name=Carson85>[[#Carson|Carson, Ashdown-Hill, Johnson, Johnson & Langley]], p. 85.</ref> The [[British Royal Family]] made no claim on the remains – Queen [[Elizabeth II]] was reportedly consulted but rejected the idea of a royal burial<ref name="BA141">{{cite news |title=The reburial of Richard III |last=Pitts |first=Mike |work=British Archaeology |issue=141 |date=March–April 2015 |pages=26–33}}</ref> – so the Ministry of Justice initially confirmed that the University of Leicester would make the final decision on where the bones should be re-buried.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/Richard-III-University-Leicester-decide-final/story-18077880-detail/story.html |title=Richard III set to be buried in Leicester as university makes final decision |work=Leicester Mercury |date=7 February 2013 |accessdate=11 February 2013}}</ref> David Monteith, [[Chancellor (ecclesiastical)|Canon Chancellor]] of Leicester Cathedral, said Richard's skeleton would be reinterred at the cathedral in early 2014 in a "Christian-led but ecumenical service",<ref>{{cite news |title=Richard III: New battle looms over final resting place |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/02/06/world/europe/uk-richard-iii-reburial |accessdate=10 June 2013 |newspaper=CNN |date=6 February 2013}}</ref> not a formal reburial but rather a service of remembrance, as a funeral service would have been held at the time of burial.<ref name="Reinterred">{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/science-news/9847738/Richard-III-to-be-re-interred-in-major-ceremony-at-Leicester-Cathedral.html|title=Richard III to be re-interred in major ceremony at Leicester Cathedral|first1=Nick|last1=Britten|first2=Andrew|last2=Hough|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Leicester Cathedral exterior.jpg|left|thumb|Leicester Cathedral, where Richard III was reburied in March 2015]]
The choice of burial site proved controversial and proposals were made for Richard to be buried in places which some felt were more fitting for a [[Roman Catholic]] and [[House of York|Yorkist]] monarch. Online petitions were launched calling for Richard to be buried in [[Westminster Abbey]],{{refn|Richard's wife [[Anne Neville]] is buried within Westminster Abbey; it is uncertain where their only child Edward of Middleham, Prince of Wales, is buried; theories have included [[Sheriff Hutton]] Church, or [[Middleham]], both in North Yorkshire.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/printable/38659 | title=Edward [Edward of Middleham], prince of Wales (1474x6–1484) | website = Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, online edition| publication-date = September 2010 | year = 2004 | last = Pollard| first = AJ | accessdate=24 August 2013 | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/38659 | publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref>|group=note}} where 17 other English and British kings are interred; [[York Minster]], which some claimed was Richard's own preferred burial site; the Roman Catholic [[Arundel Cathedral]]; or in the Leicester car park in which his body was found. Only two options received significant public support, with Leicester receiving 3,100 more signatures than York.<ref name="BA141" /> The issue was discussed in the [[Houses of Parliament]]; the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] MP and historian [[Chris Skidmore]] proposed that a state funeral should be held, while [[John Mann (British politician)|John Mann]], the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] MP for [[Bassetlaw (UK Parliament constituency)|Bassetlaw]], suggested that the body should be buried in [[Worksop]] in his constituency – halfway between York and Leicester. All options were rejected in Leicester, whose mayor [[Peter Soulsby]] retorted: "Those bones leave Leicester over my dead body."<ref name="Tug-of-war">{{cite news |title=Tug-of-war brews over 'king in car park' |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/4a7290da-6e2b-11e2-983d-00144feab49a.html |work=Financial Times |date=3 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015 |first=John Murray |last=Brown}}</ref>
After legal action brought by the "[[Plantagenet Alliance]]", a group representing claimed [[lineal descent|collateral descendants]] of Richard, his final resting place remained uncertain for nearly a year.<ref name=BBCHC>{{cite news|title=King Richard III burial row heads to High Court|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-york-north-yorkshire-22371814|publisher=BBC News|date=1 May 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> The group, which described itself as "his Majesty's representatives and voice",<ref name="BA133" /> called for Richard to be buried in York Minster, which they claimed was his "wish".<ref name=BBCHC/><ref name=BBCreburialrow>{{cite news|title=Richard III: King's reburial row goes to judicial review|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-23726011|publisher=BBC News|date=16 August 2013|accessdate=19 August 2013}}</ref> The [[Dean of Leicester]] called their challenge "disrespectful", and said that the cathedral would not invest any more money until the matter was decided.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite news|title=Richard III remains: Reinterment delay 'disrespectful'|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-23329424|accessdate=27 July 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=16 July 2013}}</ref> Historians said there was no evidence that Richard III wanted to be buried in York.<ref name="BA133" /> Mark Ormrod of the [[University of York]] expressed scepticism over the idea that Richard had devised any clear plans for his own burial.<ref>{{cite web |first=Mark |last=Ormrod |title=A burial fit for a King |publisher=University of York |date=5 February 2013 |url=http://www.york.ac.uk/news-and-events/features/richard-iii/ |accessdate=7 May 2013 }}</ref> The standing of the Plantagenet Alliance was challenged. Mathematician [[Rob Eastaway]] calculated that Richard III may have millions of living collateral descendants, saying that "we should all have the chance to vote on Leicester versus York".<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leicestershire-23757868 | title=Richard III: More or Less examines how many descendents he could have | publisher=BBC News | date=19 August 2013 | accessdate=24 August 2013}}</ref>
In August 2013 [[Charles Haddon-Cave|Justice Haddon-Cave]] granted permission for a judicial review since the original burial plans ignored the [[common law]] duty "to consult widely as to how and where Richard III's remains should appropriately be reinterred".<ref name=BBCreburialrow/> The judicial review opened on 13 March 2014 and was expected to last two days<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-leicestershire-26558933 |title=Richard III remains: Judicial review hearing starts |publisher=BBC News |date=13 March 2014 |accessdate=23 May 2014}}</ref> but the decision was deferred for four to six weeks. [[Heather Hallett|Lady Justice Hallett]], sitting with [[Duncan Ouseley|Justice Ouseley]] and Justice Haddon-Cave, said the court would take time to consider its judgment.<ref>{{cite news|title=Richard III: Judicial review bones decision deferred|url= http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-leicestershire-26576116|publisher=BBC News|date=14 March 2014|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> On 23 May the High Court ruled there was "no duty to consult" and "no public law grounds for the court to interfere", so reburial in Leicester could proceed.<ref name="BBC-23-May-2014">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-27537836 |title=Richard III reburial court bid fails |publisher=BBC News |date=23 May 2014 |accessdate=23 May 2014}}</ref> The litigation cost the defendants £245,000 – far more than the cost of the original investigation.<ref name="BA141" />
===Reburial and commemorations=== [[File:Trumna_ze_szczątkami_Króla_Ryszarda_III.jpg|right|thumb|Funeral cortège bearing Richard's coffin]] [[File:Picture_of_Richard_III's_new_tomb.jpg|right|thumb|The 2015 tomb of Richard III]] In February 2013, Leicester Cathedral announced a procedure and timetable for the reinterment of Richard's remains. The cathedral authorities planned to bury him in a "place of honour" within the cathedral.<ref name=cath>{{cite web|url=http://www.leicester.anglican.org/news/details/cathedral-announces-first-step-in-interment-process |title=Cathedral announces first step in interment process |publisher=Leicester.anglican.org |date=12 February 2013 |accessdate=8 August 2013}}</ref> Initial plans for a flat [[ledger stone]], perhaps modifying [[c:File:Memorial_to_King_Richard_III_of_England_in_Leicester_Cathedral.jpg|the memorial stone installed in the chancel in 1982]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leicester.anglican.org/site-includes/uploads/wygwam/Architects%20Brief%20for%20Grave%20of%20Richard%20III%20130313.pdf |title=Brief for Architects: Grave for King Richard III |publisher=Leicester Cathedral |accessdate=7 May 2013 }}</ref> proved unpopular. A [[table tomb]] was the most popular option among members of the Richard III Society and in polls of Leicester people.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.richardiii.net/6_1_0_learn.php#4thmay |title=Response to the Architects' Brief produced by Leicester Cathedral for King Richard III's reburial: press release |publisher=Richard III Society |date=4 May 2013 |accessdate=23 June 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=Phil |last=Stone |title=From Darkness into Light |journal=Military History Monthly |publisher=Current Publishing |location=London |volume=34 |date=July 2013 |page=10 }}</ref> In June 2014 the design was announced, in the form of a table tomb of [[Swaledale]] fossil stone.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leicestershire-27865860|title=Richard III tomb design unveiled in Leicester|publisher=BBC News|date=16 June 2014|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref> In June 2014 the statue of Richard III that had stood in Leicester's Castle Gardens was moved to the redesigned Cathedral Gardens, which were reopened on 5 July 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leicestershire-28034207|title=Leicester's Richard III statue reinstated at Cathedral Gardens|publisher=BBC News|date=26 June 2014|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref>
The reburial took place during a week of events between 22 and 27 March 2015. The sequence of events included: * '''Sunday 22 March 2015''': Richard's bones were sealed in a lead-lined [[ossuary]] and placed in a wooden coffin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leicestershire-31911490 |title=Richard III's remains sealed inside coffin at Leicester University – BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-03-25}}</ref> The remains were moved from the University of Leicester to Leicester Cathedral via the site of the Battle of Bosworth at Fenn Lane Farm and through [[Dadlington]], [[Sutton Cheney]], Bosworth Battlefield Heritage Centre on [[Ambion Hill]], and [[Market Bosworth]] retracing part of Richard's last journey.<ref name="BA141"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kingrichardinleicester.com/topics/reburial/timetable/ |title=Reburial TImetable Archives – King Richard III in Leicester |publisher=Kingrichardinleicester.com |date=2015-02-16 |accessdate=2015-03-25}}</ref> The coffin, made from [[English oak]] from the [[Duchy of Cornwall]] estate by Richard's present-day collateral mitochondrial relative Michael Ibsen,<ref name="Telegraph"/> was transferred from a motor [[hearse]] to a four-horse drawn hearse for entry into the city of Leicester.<ref name="ROTK">[[Channel 4]] television program ''Richard III, The Return of the King'', 5.10 pm to 8 pm, Sunday 22 March 2015 in Britain.</ref> * '''Monday 23 – Wednesday 25 March 2015''': Remains lay in repose in the cathedral. Waiting times to view the coffin were reported to exceed four hours.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leicestershire-32014296|title=Richard III: More than 5,000 people visit Leicester Cathedral coffin|last=Anon|date=23 March 2015|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref> * '''Monday 23 March 2015''': Cardinal [[Vincent Nichols]], the [[Archbishop of Westminster]], celebrated Mass for Richard III's soul in [[Holy Cross Priory, Leicester]], the Catholic parish church, and in [[Holy Cross Church, Leicester|Holy Cross Church]]. * '''Thursday 26 March 2015''': Reburial in the presence of [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], [[Justin Welby]], and senior members of other Christian denominations. The service, shown live on [[Channel 4]], included memorial prayers for Richard III and the victims of Bosworth and other conflicts. Actor [[Benedict Cumberbatch]], a distant relative of Richard III, read a poem written for the service by the [[Poet Laureate of the United Kingdom|poet laureate]], [[Carol Ann Duffy]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Benedict Cumberbatch to read poem at Richard III's reburial|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/03/25/europe/richard-iii-funeral-benedict-cumberbatch/index.html|accessdate=25 March 2015|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=25 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/richard-iii-the-reburial|title=Richard III: The Reburial|last=|first=|publisher=Channel Four|date=23 March 2015 |accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> The Royal Family was represented by [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex]], [[Prince Richard, Duke of Gloucester]], and his wife [[Birgitte, Duchess of Gloucester]]—[[Richard III]] was [[Duke of Gloucester]] before coming to the throne himself. Music during the service included a setting of [[Psalm 138]] by [[Leonel Power]]; ''Ghostly Grace'', an anthem composed for the service by [[Judith Bingham]]; a setting of [[Psalm 150]] by [[Philip Moore (organist)|Philip Moore]]; and an arrangement of "[[God Save the Queen]]" by [[Judith Weir]].<ref name=orderofservice>{{cite web|title=Order of Service for the Reinterment of the Remains of King Richard III|url=http://www.channel4.com/microsites/R/RichardIII/Reinterment%2026%20March%20-%20PreServiceCopy.pdf|accessdate=26 March 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150326125617/http://www.channel4.com/microsites/R/RichardIII/Reinterment%2026%20March%20-%20PreServiceCopy.pdf|archivedate=26 March 2015|date=26 March 2015}}</ref> * '''Friday 27 March 2015''': Unveiling the tomb to the public, followed by commemorations across Leicester.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leicestershire-30341032|title=Public to attend Richard III reburial at Leicester Cathedral|date=5 December 2014|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Tomb of Richard III in Leicester Cathedral.jpg|thumb|Tomb]] -->
==Reactions== [[File:Dynasty Death and Discovery, Richard III museum gallery.jpg|right|thumb|One of the galleries in the Richard III visitor centre in Leicester]] After the discovery, Leicester City Council set up a temporary exhibition about Richard III in the city's medieval [[Leicester Guildhall|guildhall]].<ref name="BBC-22-July-2014">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leicestershire-28424958|title=Does Leicester's Richard III centre live up to the hype?|last=Watson|first=Grieg|date=22 July 2014 |accessdate=23 February 2015|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> The council announced it would create a permanent attraction and subsequently spent £850,000 to buy the freehold of St Martin's Place, formerly part of [[Leicester Grammar School]], in Peacock Lane, across the road from the cathedral. The site adjoins the car park where the body was found, and overlies the chancel of Greyfriars Friary Church.<ref name="Tug-of-war" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/Leicester-City-Council-buys-site-Richard-III/story-17477308-detail/story.html|title=Leicester City Council buys the site of its Richard III centre for £850,000|first=Peter|last=Warzynski|work=Leicester Mercury|date=3 December 2012 |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> It was converted into a £4.5 million visitor centre telling the story of Richard's life, death, burial and rediscovery, with [[artifact (archaeology)|artefacts]] from the dig including Philippa Langley's [[Wellington boots]] and the hard hat and high-visibility jacket worn by archaeologist Mathew Morris on the day he found Richard's skeleton. Visitors can see the grave site under a glass floor.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/jul/22/richard-iii-visitor-centre-leicester|title=Richard III visitor centre in Leicester opens its doors to the public|last=Kennedy|first=Maev|date=22 July 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> The council anticipated that the visitor centre, which opened in July 2014, would attract 100,000 visitors a year.<ref name="BBC-22-July-2014" />
In Norway, archaeologist Øystein Ekroll hoped that the interest in the discovery of the English king would spill over to Norway. In contrast to England where, with the possible exception of [[Edward V of England|Edward V]], all the kings since the 11th century have now been discovered, in Norway about 25 medieval kings are buried in [[unmarked grave]]s around the country. Ekroll proposed to start with [[Harald Hardrada]], who was probably buried anonymously in [[Trondheim]], beneath what is today a public road. A previous attempt to exhume Harald in 2006 was blocked by the [[Norwegian Directorate for Cultural Heritage]] (''{{lang|no|Riksantikvaren}}'').<ref>{{cite news|last1=Landrø|first1=Juliet|last2=Zahl|first2=Hilde|url=http://nrk.no/vitenskap-og-teknologi/1.10900296|work=NRK|title=Ønsker å grave opp de norske "asfaltkongene"|date=5 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2015|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
Richard Buckley of the University of Leicester Archaeological Services, who said he would "eat his hat" if Richard was discovered, fulfilled his promise by eating a hat-shaped cake baked by a colleague.<ref name="Reinterred" /> Buckley later said:
{{quote|Cutting edge research has been used in the project and the work has really only just begun. The discoveries, such as the very precise carbon dating and medical evidence, will serve as a benchmark for other studies. And it is, of course, an incredible story. He's a controversial figure, people love the idea he was found under a car park, the whole thing unfolded in the most amazing way. You couldn't make it up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leicestershire-21082999|title=Richard III: Greatest archaeological discovery of all?|last=Watson|first=Grieg|date=12 February 2013 |work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref>}}
